1967  /** Schedule for execution on Hexagon. When a loop is marked with
1968  * Hexagon, that loop is executed on a Hexagon DSP. */
1969  Func &hexagon(const VarOrRVar &x = Var::outermost());
1970 
1971  /** Prefetch data written to or read from a Func or an ImageParam by a
1972  * subsequent loop iteration, at an optionally specified iteration offset.
1973  * 'var' specifies at which loop level the prefetch calls should be inserted.
1974  * The final argument specifies how prefetch of region outside bounds
1975  * should be handled.
1976  *
1977  * For example, consider this pipeline:
1978  \code
1979  Func f, g;
1980  Var x, y;
1981  f(x, y) = x + y;
1982  g(x, y) = 2 * f(x, y);
1983  \endcode
1984  *
1985  * The following schedule:
1986  \code
1987  f.compute_root();
1988  g.prefetch(f, x, 2, PrefetchBoundStrategy::NonFaulting);
1989  \endcode
1990  *
1991  * will inject prefetch call at the innermost loop of 'g' and generate
1992  * the following loop nest:
1993  * for y = ...
1994  * for x = ...
1995  * f(x, y) = x + y
1996  * for y = ..
1997  * for x = ...
1998  * prefetch(&f[x + 2, y], 1, 16);
1999  * g(x, y) = 2 * f(x, y)
2000  */
2001  // @{
2002  Func &prefetch(const Func &f, const VarOrRVar &var, Expr offset = 1,
2003  PrefetchBoundStrategy strategy = PrefetchBoundStrategy::GuardWithIf);
2004  Func &prefetch(const Internal::Parameter &param, const VarOrRVar &var, Expr offset = 1,
2005  PrefetchBoundStrategy strategy = PrefetchBoundStrategy::GuardWithIf);
2006  template<typename T>
2007  Func &prefetch(const T &image, VarOrRVar var, Expr offset = 1,
2008  PrefetchBoundStrategy strategy = PrefetchBoundStrategy::GuardWithIf) {
2009  return prefetch(image.parameter(), var, offset, strategy);
2010  }
2011  // @}
2012 
2013  /** Specify how the storage for the function is laid out. These
2014  * calls let you specify the nesting order of the dimensions. For
2015  * example, foo.reorder_storage(y, x) tells Halide to use
2016  * column-major storage for any realizations of foo, without
2017  * changing how you refer to foo in the code. You may want to do
2018  * this if you intend to vectorize across y. When representing
2019  * color images, foo.reorder_storage(c, x, y) specifies packed
2020  * storage (red, green, and blue values adjacent in memory), and
2021  * foo.reorder_storage(x, y, c) specifies planar storage (entire
2022  * red, green, and blue images one after the other in memory).
2023  *
2024  * If you leave out some dimensions, those remain in the same
2025  * positions in the nesting order while the specified variables
2026  * are reordered around them. */
2027  // @{
2028  Func &reorder_storage(const std::vector<Var> &dims);
2029 
2030  Func &reorder_storage(const Var &x, const Var &y);
2031  template<typename... Args>
2032  HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE typename std::enable_if<Internal::all_are_convertible<Var, Args...>::value, Func &>::type
2033  reorder_storage(const Var &x, const Var &y, Args &&...args) {
2034  std::vector<Var> collected_args{x, y, std::forward<Args>(args)...};
2035  return reorder_storage(collected_args);
2036  }
2037  // @}
2038 
2039  /** Pad the storage extent of a particular dimension of
2040  * realizations of this function up to be a multiple of the
2041  * specified alignment. This guarantees that the strides for the
2042  * dimensions stored outside of dim will be multiples of the
2043  * specified alignment, where the strides and alignment are
2044  * measured in numbers of elements.
2045  *
2046  * For example, to guarantee that a function foo(x, y, c)
2047  * representing an image has scanlines starting on offsets
2048  * aligned to multiples of 16, use foo.align_storage(x, 16). */
2049  Func &align_storage(const Var &dim, const Expr &alignment);
2050 
2051  /** Store realizations of this function in a circular buffer of a
2052  * given extent. This is more efficient when the extent of the
2053  * circular buffer is a power of 2. If the fold factor is too
2054  * small, or the dimension is not accessed monotonically, the
2055  * pipeline will generate an error at runtime.
2056  *
2057  * The fold_forward option indicates that the new values of the
2058  * producer are accessed by the consumer in a monotonically
2059  * increasing order. Folding storage of producers is also
2060  * supported if the new values are accessed in a monotonically
2061  * decreasing order by setting fold_forward to false.
2062  *
2063  * For example, consider the pipeline:
2064  \code
2065  Func f, g;
2066  Var x, y;
2067  g(x, y) = x*y;
2068  f(x, y) = g(x, y) + g(x, y+1);
2069  \endcode
2070  *
2071  * If we schedule f like so:
2072  *
2073  \code
2074  g.compute_at(f, y).store_root().fold_storage(y, 2);
2075  \endcode
2076  *
2077  * Then g will be computed at each row of f and stored in a buffer
2078  * with an extent in y of 2, alternately storing each computed row
2079  * of g in row y=0 or y=1.
2080  */
2081  Func &fold_storage(const Var &dim, const Expr &extent, bool fold_forward = true);
2082 
2083  /** Compute this function as needed for each unique value of the
2084  * given var for the given calling function f.
2085  *
2086  * For example, consider the simple pipeline:
2087  \code
2088  Func f, g;
2089  Var x, y;
2090  g(x, y) = x*y;
2091  f(x, y) = g(x, y) + g(x, y+1) + g(x+1, y) + g(x+1, y+1);
2092  \endcode
2093  *
2094  * If we schedule f like so:
2095  *
2096  \code
2097  g.compute_at(f, x);
2098  \endcode
2099  *
2100  * Then the C code equivalent to this pipeline will look like this
2101  *
2102  \code
2103 
2104  int f[height][width];
2105  for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2106  for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2107  int g[2][2];
2108  g[0][0] = x*y;
2109  g[0][1] = (x+1)*y;
2110  g[1][0] = x*(y+1);
2111  g[1][1] = (x+1)*(y+1);
2112  f[y][x] = g[0][0] + g[1][0] + g[0][1] + g[1][1];
2113  }
2114  }
2115 
2116  \endcode
2117  *
2118  * The allocation and computation of g is within f's loop over x,
2119  * and enough of g is computed to satisfy all that f will need for
2120  * that iteration. This has excellent locality - values of g are
2121  * used as soon as they are computed, but it does redundant
2122  * work. Each value of g ends up getting computed four times. If
2123  * we instead schedule f like so:
2124  *
2125  \code
2126  g.compute_at(f, y);
2127  \endcode
2128  *
2129  * The equivalent C code is:
2130  *
2131  \code
2132  int f[height][width];
2133  for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2134  int g[2][width+1];
2135  for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2136  g[0][x] = x*y;
2137  g[1][x] = x*(y+1);
2138  }
2139  for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2140  f[y][x] = g[0][x] + g[1][x] + g[0][x+1] + g[1][x+1];
2141  }
2142  }
2143  \endcode
2144  *
2145  * The allocation and computation of g is within f's loop over y,
2146  * and enough of g is computed to satisfy all that f will need for
2147  * that iteration. This does less redundant work (each point in g
2148  * ends up being evaluated twice), but the locality is not quite
2149  * as good, and we have to allocate more temporary memory to store
2150  * g.
2151  */
2152  Func &compute_at(const Func &f, const Var &var);
2153 
2154  /** Schedule a function to be computed within the iteration over
2155  * some dimension of an update domain. Produces equivalent code
2156  * to the version of compute_at that takes a Var. */
2157  Func &compute_at(const Func &f, const RVar &var);
2158 
2159  /** Schedule a function to be computed within the iteration over
2160  * a given LoopLevel. */
2161  Func &compute_at(LoopLevel loop_level);
2162 
2163  /** Schedule the iteration over the initial definition of this function
2164  * to be fused with another stage 's' from outermost loop to a
2165  * given LoopLevel. */
2166  // @{
2167  Func &compute_with(const Stage &s, const VarOrRVar &var, const std::vector<std::pair<VarOrRVar, LoopAlignStrategy>> &align);
2168  Func &compute_with(const Stage &s, const VarOrRVar &var, LoopAlignStrategy align = LoopAlignStrategy::Auto);
2169  Func &compute_with(LoopLevel loop_level, const std::vector<std::pair<VarOrRVar, LoopAlignStrategy>> &align);
2170  Func &compute_with(LoopLevel loop_level, LoopAlignStrategy align = LoopAlignStrategy::Auto);
2171 
2172  /** Compute all of this function once ahead of time. Reusing
2173  * the example in \ref Func::compute_at :
2174  *
2175  \code
2176  Func f, g;
2177  Var x, y;
2178  g(x, y) = x*y;
2179  f(x, y) = g(x, y) + g(x, y+1) + g(x+1, y) + g(x+1, y+1);
2180 
2181  g.compute_root();
2182  \endcode
2183  *
2184  * is equivalent to
2185  *
2186  \code
2187  int f[height][width];
2188  int g[height+1][width+1];
2189  for (int y = 0; y < height+1; y++) {
2190  for (int x = 0; x < width+1; x++) {
2191  g[y][x] = x*y;
2192  }
2193  }
2194  for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2195  for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2196  f[y][x] = g[y][x] + g[y+1][x] + g[y][x+1] + g[y+1][x+1];
2197  }
2198  }
2199  \endcode
2200  *
2201  * g is computed once ahead of time, and enough is computed to
2202  * satisfy all uses of it. This does no redundant work (each point
2203  * in g is evaluated once), but has poor locality (values of g are
2204  * probably not still in cache when they are used by f), and
2205  * allocates lots of temporary memory to store g.
2206  */
2207  Func &compute_root();
2208 
2209  /** Use the halide_memoization_cache_... interface to store a
2210  * computed version of this function across invocations of the
2211  * Func.
2212  *
2213  * If an eviction_key is provided, it must be constructed with
2214  * Expr of integer or handle type. The key Expr will be promoted
2215  * to a uint64_t and can be used with halide_memoization_cache_evict
2216  * to remove memoized entries using this eviction key from the
2217  * cache. Memoized computations that do not provide an eviction
2218  * key will never be evicted by this mechanism.
2219  */
2220  Func &memoize(const EvictionKey &eviction_key = EvictionKey());
2221 
2222  /** Produce this Func asynchronously in a separate
2223  * thread. Consumers will be run by the task system when the
2224  * production is complete. If this Func's store level is different
2225  * to its compute level, consumers will be run concurrently,
2226  * blocking as necessary to prevent reading ahead of what the
2227  * producer has computed. If storage is folded, then the producer
2228  * will additionally not be permitted to run too far ahead of the
2229  * consumer, to avoid clobbering data that has not yet been
2230  * used.
2231  *
2232  * Take special care when combining this with custom thread pool
2233  * implementations, as avoiding deadlock with producer-consumer
2234  * parallelism requires a much more sophisticated parallel runtime
2235  * than with data parallelism alone. It is strongly recommended
2236  * you just use Halide's default thread pool, which guarantees no
2237  * deadlock and a bound on the number of threads launched.
2238  */
2239  Func &async();
2240 
2241  /** Allocate storage for this function within f's loop over
2242  * var. Scheduling storage is optional, and can be used to
2243  * separate the loop level at which storage occurs from the loop
2244  * level at which computation occurs to trade off between locality
2245  * and redundant work. This can open the door for two types of
2246  * optimization.
2247  *
2248  * Consider again the pipeline from \ref Func::compute_at :
2249  \code
2250  Func f, g;
2251  Var x, y;
2252  g(x, y) = x*y;
2253  f(x, y) = g(x, y) + g(x+1, y) + g(x, y+1) + g(x+1, y+1);
2254  \endcode
2255  *
2256  * If we schedule it like so:
2257  *
2258  \code
2259  g.compute_at(f, x).store_at(f, y);
2260  \endcode
2261  *
2262  * Then the computation of g takes place within the loop over x,
2263  * but the storage takes place within the loop over y:
2264  *
2265  \code
2266  int f[height][width];
2267  for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2268  int g[2][width+1];
2269  for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2270  g[0][x] = x*y;
2271  g[0][x+1] = (x+1)*y;
2272  g[1][x] = x*(y+1);
2273  g[1][x+1] = (x+1)*(y+1);
2274  f[y][x] = g[0][x] + g[1][x] + g[0][x+1] + g[1][x+1];
2275  }
2276  }
2277  \endcode
2278  *
2279  * Provided the for loop over x is serial, halide then
2280  * automatically performs the following sliding window
2281  * optimization:
2282  *
2283  \code
2284  int f[height][width];
2285  for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2286  int g[2][width+1];
2287  for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2288  if (x == 0) {
2289  g[0][x] = x*y;
2290  g[1][x] = x*(y+1);
2291  }
2292  g[0][x+1] = (x+1)*y;
2293  g[1][x+1] = (x+1)*(y+1);
2294  f[y][x] = g[0][x] + g[1][x] + g[0][x+1] + g[1][x+1];
2295  }
2296  }
2297  \endcode
2298  *
2299  * Two of the assignments to g only need to be done when x is
2300  * zero. The rest of the time, those sites have already been
2301  * filled in by a previous iteration. This version has the
2302  * locality of compute_at(f, x), but allocates more memory and
2303  * does much less redundant work.
2304  *
2305  * Halide then further optimizes this pipeline like so:
2306  *
2307  \code
2308  int f[height][width];
2309  for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2310  int g[2][2];
2311  for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2312  if (x == 0) {
2313  g[0][0] = x*y;
2314  g[1][0] = x*(y+1);
2315  }
2316  g[0][(x+1)%2] = (x+1)*y;
2317  g[1][(x+1)%2] = (x+1)*(y+1);
2318  f[y][x] = g[0][x%2] + g[1][x%2] + g[0][(x+1)%2] + g[1][(x+1)%2];
2319  }
2320  }
2321  \endcode
2322  *
2323  * Halide has detected that it's possible to use a circular buffer
2324  * to represent g, and has reduced all accesses to g modulo 2 in
2325  * the x dimension. This optimization only triggers if the for
2326  * loop over x is serial, and if halide can statically determine
2327  * some power of two large enough to cover the range needed. For
2328  * powers of two, the modulo operator compiles to more efficient
2329  * bit-masking. This optimization reduces memory usage, and also
2330  * improves locality by reusing recently-accessed memory instead
2331  * of pulling new memory into cache.
2332  *
2333  */
2334  Func &store_at(const Func &f, const Var &var);
2335 
2336  /** Equivalent to the version of store_at that takes a Var, but
2337  * schedules storage within the loop over a dimension of a
2338  * reduction domain */
2339  Func &store_at(const Func &f, const RVar &var);
2340 
2341  /** Equivalent to the version of store_at that takes a Var, but
2342  * schedules storage at a given LoopLevel. */
2343  Func &store_at(LoopLevel loop_level);
2344 
2345  /** Equivalent to \ref Func::store_at, but schedules storage
2346  * outside the outermost loop. */
2347  Func &store_root();
2348 
2349  /** Aggressively inline all uses of this function. This is the
2350  * default schedule, so you're unlikely to need to call this. For
2351  * a Func with an update definition, that means it gets computed
2352  * as close to the innermost loop as possible.
2353  *
2354  * Consider once more the pipeline from \ref Func::compute_at :
2355  *
2356  \code
2357  Func f, g;
2358  Var x, y;
2359  g(x, y) = x*y;
2360  f(x, y) = g(x, y) + g(x+1, y) + g(x, y+1) + g(x+1, y+1);
2361  \endcode
2362  *
2363  * Leaving g as inline, this compiles to code equivalent to the following C:
2364  *
2365  \code
2366  int f[height][width];
2367  for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2368  for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2369  f[y][x] = x*y + x*(y+1) + (x+1)*y + (x+1)*(y+1);
2370  }
2371  }
2372  \endcode
2373  */
2374  Func &compute_inline();
2375 
2376  /** Get a handle on an update step for the purposes of scheduling
2377  * it. */
2378  Stage update(int idx = 0);
2379 
2380  /** Set the type of memory this Func should be stored in. Controls
2381  * whether allocations go on the stack or the heap on the CPU, and
2382  * in global vs shared vs local on the GPU. See the documentation
2383  * on MemoryType for more detail. */
2384  Func &store_in(MemoryType memory_type);
2385 
2386  /** Trace all loads from this Func by emitting calls to
2387  * halide_trace. If the Func is inlined, this has no
2388  * effect. */
2389  Func &trace_loads();

2394  Func &trace_stores();

2451 namespace Internal {
2452 
2453 template<typename Last>
2454 inline void check_types(const Tuple &t, int idx) {
2455  using T = typename std::remove_pointer<typename std::remove_reference<Last>::type>::type;
2456  user_assert(t[idx].type() == type_of<T>())
2457  << "Can't evaluate expression "
2458  << t[idx] << " of type " << t[idx].type()
2459  << " as a scalar of type " << type_of<T>() << "\n";
2460 }
2461 
2462 template<typename First, typename Second, typename... Rest>
2463 inline void check_types(const Tuple &t, int idx) {
2464  check_types<First>(t, idx);
2465  check_types<Second, Rest...>(t, idx + 1);
2466 }
2467 
2468 template<typename Last>
2469 inline void assign_results(Realization &r, int idx, Last last) {
2470  using T = typename std::remove_pointer<typename std::remove_reference<Last>::type>::type;
2471  *last = Buffer<T>(r[idx])();
2472 }
2473 
2474 template<typename First, typename Second, typename... Rest>
2475 inline void assign_results(Realization &r, int idx, First first, Second second, Rest &&...rest) {
2476  assign_results<First>(r, idx, first);
2477  assign_results<Second, Rest...>(r, idx + 1, second, rest...);
2478 }
2479 
2480 } // namespace Internal
2481 
2482 /** JIT-Compile and run enough code to evaluate a Halide
2483  * expression. This can be thought of as a scalar version of
2484  * \ref Func::realize */
2485 template<typename T>
2486 HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE T evaluate(const Expr &e) {
2487  user_assert(e.type() == type_of<T>())
2488  << "Can't evaluate expression "
2489  << e << " of type " << e.type()
2490  << " as a scalar of type " << type_of<T>() << "\n";
2491  Func f;
2492  f() = e;
2493  Buffer<T> im = f.realize();
2494  return im();
2495 }
2496 
2497 /** JIT-compile and run enough code to evaluate a Halide Tuple. */
2498 template<typename First, typename... Rest>
2499 HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE void evaluate(Tuple t, First first, Rest &&...rest) {
2500  Internal::check_types<First, Rest...>(t, 0);
2501 
2502  Func f;
2503  f() = t;
2504  Realization r = f.realize();
2505  Internal::assign_results(r, 0, first, rest...);
2506 }
2507 
2508 namespace Internal {
2509 
2510 inline void schedule_scalar(Func f) {
2511  Target t = get_jit_target_from_environment();
2512  if (t.has_gpu_feature()) {
2513  f.gpu_single_thread();
2514  }
2515  if (t.has_feature(Target::HVX)) {
2516  f.hexagon();
2517  }
2518 }
2519 
2520 } // namespace Internal
2521 
2522 /** JIT-Compile and run enough code to evaluate a Halide
2523  * expression. This can be thought of as a scalar version of
2524  * \ref Func::realize. Can use GPU if jit target from environment
2525  * specifies one.
2526  */
2527 template<typename T>
2528 HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE T evaluate_may_gpu(const Expr &e) {
2529  user_assert(e.type() == type_of<T>())
2530  << "Can't evaluate expression "
2531  << e << " of type " << e.type()
2532  << " as a scalar of type " << type_of<T>() << "\n";
2533  Func f;
2534  f() = e;
2535  Internal::schedule_scalar(f);
2536  Buffer<T> im = f.realize();
2537  return im();
2538 }
2539 
2540 /** JIT-compile and run enough code to evaluate a Halide Tuple. Can
2541  * use GPU if jit target from environment specifies one. */
2542 // @{
2543 template<typename First, typename... Rest>
2544 HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE void evaluate_may_gpu(Tuple t, First first, Rest &&...rest) {
2545  Internal::check_types<First, Rest...>(t, 0);
2546 
2547  Func f;
2548  f() = t;
2549  Internal::schedule_scalar(f);
2550  Realization r = f.realize();
2551  Internal::assign_results(r, 0, first, rest...);
2552 }
2553 // @}
2554 
2555 } // namespace Halide
